standard_metadata.standard_description: Relate volume to the operations of multiplication and addition and solve real world and mathematical problems involving volume.

question.content: These prisms are made from the same size unit cubes.  **Which rectangular prism has greater volume?**   *Some of the cubes might be hidden behind other cubes. Try to visualize all of the cubes.*

images.alt: The front face of the rectangular prism has 16 cubes: 4 rows, 4 columns. The top face of the rectangular prism has 8 cubes: 2 rows, 4 columns. The right-hand side face of the rectangular prism has 8 cubes: 4 rows, 2 columns.

The front face of the rectangular prism has 12 cubes: 3 rows, 4 columns. The top face of the rectangular prism has 12 cubes: 3 rows, 4 columns. The right-hand side face of the rectangular prism has 9 cubes: 3 rows, 3 columns.

hints.content: We can see that there are $8$ cubes on each layer of the $\maroonD{\text{first prism}}$.  There are $4$ layers, so we can find the total number of cubes by multiplying.    $8\times 4= \maroonD{32}$   unit cubes  [[☃ image 1]]  We can also think of the volume formula.    $V = l\times w\times h$   $V = 4\times 2\times 4= \maroonD{32}$   unit cubes

images.alt: A rectangular prism shown in two parts: The top layer is shown separately from the 3 bottom layers. The front face of the top layer has 4 cubes: 1 row, 4 columns. The top face of the top layer has 8 cubes: 2 rows, 4 columns. The right-hand side face of the top layer has 2 cubes: 1 row, 2 columns. The front face of the 3 bottom layers has 12 cubes: 3 rows, 4 columns. The top face of the 3 bottom layers has 8 cubes: 2 rows, 4 columns. The right-hand side face of the 3 bottom layers has 6 cubes: 3 rows, 2 columns.

hints.content: We can see that there are $12$ cubes on each layer of the $\blueD{\text{second prism}}$. There are $3$ layers, so we can find the total number of cubes by multiplying.    $12\times 3= \blueD{36}$   unit cubes  [[☃ image 1]]  We can also solve using the volume formula.    $V = l\times w\times h$   $V = 4\times 3\times 3= \blueD{36}$   unit cubes

images.alt: A rectangular prism shown in two parts: The top layer is shown separately from the 2 bottom layers. The front face of the top layer has 4 cubes: 1 row, 4 columns. The top face of the top layer has 12 cubes: 3 rows, 4 columns. The right-hand side face of the top layer has 3 cubes: 1 row, 3 columns. The front face of the 2 bottom layers has 8 cubes: 2 rows, 4 columns. The top face of the 2 bottom layers has 12 cubes: 3 rows, 4 columns. The right-hand side face of the 2 bottom layers has 6 cubes: 2 rows, 3 columns.

hints.content: The $\blueD{\text{second rectangular prism}}$ has greater volume.    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: The front face of the rectangular prism has 12 cubes: 3 rows, 4 columns. The top face of the rectangular prism has 12 cubes: 3 rows, 4 columns. The right-hand side face of the rectangular prism has 9 cubes: 3 rows, 3 columns.

There are $5$ layers, so we can find the total number of cubes by multiplying.    $6\times 5= \maroonD{30}$   unit cubes   [[☃ image 1]]  We can also think of the volume formula.    $V = l\times w\times h$   $V = 2\times 3\times 5= \maroonD{30}$  unit cubes
